text: Constance Adams (16 July, 1964 – 25 June, 2018) was an American space architect. She worked in the space program. In the late 1990s she was employed by Lockheed Martin Space Operations, to support the NASA’s Mars exploration research efforts at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, Texas. Among other projects, Adams was involved in developing the Lockheed-Martin design of an inflatable module for the International Space Station.Adams, Constance, Kriss J. Kennedy. “ISS TransHab: A Space Inflatable Habitation Module” Proceedings of Space 2000: The Seventh International Conference and Exposition on Engineering, Construction, Operations and Business in Space (2000); American Society of Civil Engineers, Reston VA Adams died of colorectal cancer in Houston on June 25, 2018, aged 53. ==References== Category:Writers from Houston Category:American architects Category:Deaths from colorectal cancer Category:Cancer deaths in Texas Category:1964 births Category:2018 deaths
title: Constance Adams
